channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Southern Russian Region Rocked By Explosions
item.description: Russian officials said air defenses shot down two drones in and around Rostov-on-Don, home to Russia’s southern military headquarters. Ukraine did not immediately comment.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene of a missile strike where at least 17 people were killed at a busy market on Wednesday in Kostyantynivka, Ukraine.

item.title: South Sudanese Flee War in Sudan
item.description: Hundreds of thousands fled a grisly civil conflict years ago to settle in Sudan, to the north. With war now raging there, they are streaming home to a country ill-prepared to take them back.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Joao Silva
item.media:description: Nyamut Gai, 28, and her family years ago fled a bloody civil war in South Sudan for the safety of Sudan. But after war broke out in Sudan, she made the weekslong trip back home, losing two children to disease and hunger along the way.

item.title: Extreme Weather in Greece Traps Residents and Submerges Villages
item.description: Greek military forces were called in to assist the rescue efforts. At least four people in Greece and at least nine in neighboring Turkey have died this week amid torrential rains and flooding.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Floodwater covering the village of Flamouli on Thursday in central Greece.

item.title: Can India’s Global Ambitions Survive Its Deepening Chasms at Home?
item.description: India’s hosting of the G20 summit this weekend will put its growing power on display. But its leader’s divisive religious politics threaten its rise.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents packing their belongings after clashes in the state of Haryana last month in the shadow of the burgeoning tech hub of Gurugram.

item.title: Ukrainians Embrace Cluster Munitions, but Are They Helping?
item.description: The weapons, banned by most countries over human rights concerns, are “not a magic wand,” but some Ukrainian troops say they are making a difference in fighting Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier firing a 155 mm howitzer, the type of weapon used to launch cluster munitions, in the Donetsk region in March.

item.title: Spain’s Female Soccer Players Strike Over Wage Dispute
item.description: The season was scheduled to begin on Friday, but the players refused to play after talks with the league brought no agreement. The dispute comes amid a debate over sexism and soccer in Spain.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes and Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: Members of Spain’s national team warming up before the Women’s World Cup final in Sydney, Australia, last month.

item.title: Gabon Military Says Deposed President Is Free to Leave the Country
item.description: Before Ali Bongo Ondimba was ousted in late August, he and his family had ruled over the oil-rich central African state for more than half a century.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Gabon 24, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ali Bongo Ondimba, left, the ousted president of Gabon, receiving Abdou Abarry of the United Nations office for central Africa, at his home in Libreville, in an image from state-run television.

item.title: Palestinian Leader’s Antisemitic Comments Cause Uproar
item.description: Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, said in August that European Jews were persecuted for what he said were their predatory lending practices, not their religion.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, in Ramallah in January. Mr. Abbas has a long history of comments that have drawn accusations of antisemitism.

item.title: Mexico’s Next President Will Be a Woman
item.description: Mexico will elect its first woman as president next year after the governing party chose Claudia Sheinbaum to square off against the opposition’s candidate, Xóchitl Gálvez.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum in her office in 2020, when she served as the mayor of Mexico City.

item.title: Teams in Turkey Try to Rescue Sick American From Underground Cave
item.description: Mark Dickey, an American cave specialist, fell ill and was unable to climb out on his own. Medical teams say his condition is improving.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: National Cave Rescue Commission, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo released by the National Cave Rescue Commission shows Mark Dickey in Mentone, Ala., in May.

item.title: Slovakia Election Could Shift Sentiment in a Fierce Ukraine Ally
item.description: The vote in Slovakia this month will be a test of European unity on Ukraine, and of Russia’s efforts to undermine it. The front-runner wants to halt arms shipments to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Robert Fico, a former prime minister of Slovakia and the front-runner in the election, opposes helping Ukraine. The vote will show whether that stance could take hold in Europe’s political mainstream.

item.title: Bali Elevator Plunges Into Ravine, Killing 5
item.description: The five victims of the accident in Bali, an island that drives Indonesia’s tourism economy, were young housekeepers. Only one had a full-time contract.
item.dc:creator: Dera Menra Sijabat and Mike Ives

item.title: After 3 Weeks of Wildfire Exile, Yellowknife Residents Return Home
item.description: The residents of Yellowknife, the capital of the Northwest Territories of Canada, were ordered out last month when a wildfire came near their city.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Bill Braden/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Aurora Borealis glowed over evacuees from Yellowknife last month at a campsite in High Level, Alberta.

item.title: At Least 37 Dead After Flooding From Cyclone in Brazil
item.description: More than 3,500 people were displaced as towns flooded in the states of Rio Grande do Sul and Santa Catarina. Rains were forecast to continue.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Mateus Bruxel/Agencia RBS, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Flooding in Muçum, Rio Grande do Sul State, Brazil, on Tuesday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Mexico decriminalizes abortion.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A sign in Mexico City earlier this year read, “Abortion out of the penal code.”

item.title: U.S. Seized Iranian Oil Over Smuggling Incident That Escalated Tensions in Gulf
item.description: The apprehension of the ship, the Suez Rajan, came after a group opposed to Iran raised accusations of sanctions violations last year.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: The advocacy group United Against Nuclear Iran said this satellite image shows the Virgo, left, and the M/T Suez Rajan in the South China Sea. At the time the image was taken, the Virgo reported a false location of about eight miles away.

item.title: Nairy Baghramian Breaks Through With Metropolitan Museum Facade Commission
item.description: With powerfully alive new works at the Met and MoMA, the Iranian-born artist Nairy Baghramian embraces the canon, the better to take it apart.
item.dc:creator: Siddhartha Mitter
item.media:credit: Mustafah Abdulaziz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nairy Baghramian in her Berlin studio. “A vertical swimming pool doesn’t exist, but I would like to swim in it,” she said. “There’s no such thing as a horizontal staircase — but I would like to imagine it.”

item.title: Blinken Visits Ukraine as Russian Missile Strike Kills 17
item.description: A Russian missile killed at least 17 civilians and wounded dozens, while Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken vowed lasting backing and announced a new round of aid.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene of a missile strike where at least 17 people were killed and 32 wounded at a busy market on Wednesday in Kostyantynivka, Ukraine.

item.title: Mexico’s Supreme Court Decriminalizes Abortion Nationwide
item.description: The decision builds on an earlier high court ruling and reflects how Latin American countries are expanding women’s rights.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Women marching last year in Mexico City during a demonstration on International Safe Abortion Day.

item.title: Suspected Russian Drone Debris Found in Romania
item.description: The Romanian president, Klaus Iohannis, said that if the wreckage was confirmed to be Russian, it would be “a serious violation” of a NATO member’s sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Fishermen in Plauru, Romania, just across the Danube River from the Ukrainian port of Izmail on Tuesday.

item.title: G20 Invitation Called India ‘Bharat,’ Setting Off Debate
item.description: Group of 20 leaders who’ll meet in India got a letter from the “President of Bharat,” a politically charged name for the country that’s popular with Hindu nationalists.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India attending Independence Day celebrations in New Delhi last month.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Blinken Visits Kyiv
item.description: Plus, the deadliest missile attack in Ukraine in months.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kostyantynivka, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Nigerian Court Rejects Challenges to Contested Presidential Election
item.description: The tribunal confirmed the election of President Bola Tinubu, who has faced growing discontent amid unpopular economic policies and lingering allegations of irregularities in the election.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: President-elect Bola Tinubu, center, gestures to supporters after receiving his certificate at a ceremony in Abuja, Nigeria, in March.

item.title: Mexico City Marathon Opens Investigation After Cheating Claims
item.description: In previous years, thousands of runners have been disqualified for course cutting. Runners are under scrutiny again.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Víctor Manuel Ramos
item.media:description: Thousands of people have been disqualified from the Mexico City Marathon in the past decade.

item.title: Huawei Phone Is Latest Shot Fired in the U.S.-China Tech War
item.description: The release of a homegrown Chinese smartphone during a visit by the Biden official in charge of regulating such technology shows the U.S.-China tech conflict is alive and well.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Huawei store in Shanghai. Huawei’s jade-green Mate 60 Pro appears to have many of the same basic capabilities as other smartphones on the market.

item.title: U.K. Police Hunt Daniel Abed Khalife, Terror Suspect Who Escaped London Prison
item.description: A former British Army soldier, Daniel Abed Khalife, broke out of prison while awaiting trial on charges of breaking the Official Secrets Act and terrorism-related offenses.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: The escape took place from the Wandsworth prison in southwest London on Wednesday.

item.title: In Mexico, Drug Trade Flourished With the Help of the State
item.description: An article sheds light on a notorious cold case.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posters in Mexico City of some of the 43 students who were kidnapped in 2014 by the police and turned over to a cartel.

item.title: Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey Are Hit By Floods, Killing 14
item.description: The floodwaters ravaged bridges, stranded tourists and swept away cars and buildings. Thousands of households were still cut off from power on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Isabella Kwai

item.title: Sexism in Spanish Women’s Soccer: Bedtime Check-Ins and Verbal Abuse
item.description: More than a dozen women described sexism ranging from paternalism to verbal abuse. “What you really need is a good man,” a former national captain said players were told.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler, Sarah Hurtes and Jeré Longman
item.media:description: Members of the Spanish soccer team before the Women’s World Cup final in Sydney, Australia, last month.

item.title: With Aid on the Line, Biden Officials Debate ‘Coup’ Finding for Niger
item.description: American officials have tap danced around a word that would prompt a cutoff of U.S. assistance to a valued African ally.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Supporters of the military takeover with a Russian flag in Niamey, Niger’s capital, in July. The Biden administration worries that severing ties with Niger might give Russia an opportunity to expand its influence.

item.title: Jenni Hermoso Files Complaint in Spain Over Rubiales Kiss at World Cup
item.description: Jennifer Hermoso has said the kiss from Luis Rubiales, head of the Spanish soccer federation, at the women’s World Cup was not consensual. The scandal has grown into a reckoning over sexism.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: Jennifer Hermoso warming up before the Women’s World Cup final in Sydney last month. The kiss came in the wake of her team’s victory.

item.title: Russian Missile Strike Leaves Scene of Carnage at Market in Ukraine
item.description: A Russian missile strike in Kostyantynivka that killed at least 17 and injured more than 30 others was one of the deadliest in months.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta, Lynsey Addario and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Office via Associated Press

item.title: British Bees Face a Deadly Invasion
item.description: The number of sightings of Asian hornets, an invasive species that can wipe out bee colonies, has spiked this year, raising concerns among British beekeepers.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Axel Heimken/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Asian hornets were first detected in France in 2005 and have since spread to other European countries, as well as Britain.

item.title: UK Air Traffic Control Chaos Was a ‘1 in 15 Million’ Problem
item.description: Air traffic computer systems shut down after receiving duplicate data, a report found, forcing plans to be processed manually.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Hundreds of flights in and out of Britain were delayed or canceled on Aug. 28 and 29 because of a technical failure.

item.title: Mass Hunger Strike in Bahrain Prison Sets Off Rare Protests
item.description: In a kingdom that crushed an Arab Spring uprising more than a decade ago, prisoners are now on hunger strike to demand better conditions, fueling protests in support of their cause.
item.dc:creator: Nazeeha Saeed and Vivian Nereim
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: A satellite photo taken in July of the Jau prison in Bahrain, where prisoners are almost a month into a hunger strike.

item.title: How to Spot a Wildfire: Weighing Fire Lookouts and Technology
item.description: Officials say the future of wildfire detection is cameras. But in northwest Montana, solitary humans on mountaintops still do more than machines alone can offer.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Mark Felix
item.media:description: Leif Haugen with his morning coffee at the Thoma firetower lookout in the Flathead National Forest in Montana.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Seoul
item.description: Han Kang grew up in Seoul, a city that embraces “thousands of years of turbulence.” She recommends reading that draws from the various eras that have made up her hometown.
item.dc:creator: Han Kang and translated by Jasmine Jeemin Lee

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A possible advance by Ukraine’s army.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen riding a tank near the village of Robotyne, in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region, last month.

item.title: G20 Summit in India: Why It Still Matters and What to Expect
item.description: Summits like the one in India this weekend have produced many ambitious statements — and, often, disappointing results. Critics say an upgrade is needed.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: President Biden, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany during the Group of 20 summit in Indonesia last year.

item.title: China’s Economic Pain Is a Test of Xi’s Fixation With Control
item.description: The slowdown is posing perhaps the most sustained challenge to President Xi Jinping’s agenda in over a decade in power. He now faces a tangle of difficult choices.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping’s strategy of ruling of China through highly centralized control is under pressure.

item.title: Ex-Colombian Soldier Is Set to Plead Guilty in Killing of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti
item.description: A former Colombian Army captain who is accused of playing a leading role in the 2021 killing will change his plea to guilty, a sign that he may testify against his co-defendants.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural depicting the assassinated president of Haiti, Jovenel Moïse, near the entrance to his home in Pétionville.

item.title: Leaders of Canadian Trucker Protest Go on Trial
item.description: Two key organizers of the 2022 trucker protest argued that their efforts were a form of free speech, as prosecutors asserted that “this case is not about their political views.”
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers began to make arrests at the trucker protest in Ottawa in February 2022.

item.title: Workers Use Excavator to Plow Through Great Wall of China
item.description: The pair, a 38-year-old man and 55-year-old woman, used an excavator to widen an existing gap and make a shortcut, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka, Yan Zhuang and Siyi Zhao
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Youyu County Public Security Bureau, via Reuters
item.media:description: Two workers were accused of causing “irreversible damage” to a section of the Great Wall of China, where they were accused of using an excavator to widen a gap, according to the Youyu County Public Security Bureau.

item.title: Ukraine Tries to Breach Russian Lines in Another Patch of Territory
item.description: Ukrainian soldiers are trying to build on a new breach in enemy lines, but the battle will not be easy, military analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Destruction near the village of Robotyne, in the Zaporizhzhia region of Ukraine, late last month.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine’s Next Move
item.description: Also, India’s G20 public relations blitz.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen riding a tank near the village of Robotyne, in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region, last month.

item.title: Record Rains Flood Greece, Turkey and Bulgaria, Killing at Least 7
item.description: The deluge caused extensive damage and a death in Greece, just as firefighters contained blazes there. Floods in Bulgaria and Turkey also led to six fatalities in total.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Rising water in Volos, Greece, on Tuesday. The mayor, Achilleas Beos, shouted at motorists in partly submerged cars, “Where are you going? This is insane! Go home!”

item.title: Graft in military spending becomes a headache for Ukraine.
item.description: The removal of Ukraine’s defense minister highlights the enduring challenge of corruption in Ukraine, which has emerged as a rare area of criticism of President Volodymyr Zelensky’s leadership.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian Army soldiers unloaded munitions from the back of a truck last week. Irregularities in procurement of weapons have been a persistent challenge for Ukraine.

item.title: Cuba Uncovers a Russian Human Trafficking Ring For the War in Ukraine
item.description: The Cuban government said it had begun criminal proceedings against a “trafficking network” that had been recruiting its citizens in both Russia and Cuba for Russia’s armed forces.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest blessing conscripted men at a recruiting office in Moscow in 2022. The Russian government has taken a number of measures to bolster its military ranks.

item.title: Jorge Vilda, Coach of Spain’s Women’s Soccer Team, Is Fired
item.description: Players had accused the coach, Jorge Vilda, of outdated methods and controlling behavior. His boss, Luis Rubiales, is still embroiled in scandal over a nonconsensual kiss.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: Jorge Vilda, the head coach of the Spanish women’s soccer team, after the team’s victory in the World Cup final in Australia last month.

item.title: Biden Picks Jack Lew as Envoy to Israel During Time of Friction
item.description: Mr. Lew, a former Treasury secretary, would bring stature and a low-key style to the assignment of representing the president to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Jacob J. Lew served in the Obama and Clinton administrations before being nominated by President Biden to be the next ambassador to Israel.

item.title: Battlefield Update: The entrenchments Ukraine is encountering are ‘not as strong,’ an army spokesman says.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen riding a tank near the village of Robotyne, in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region, last month.

item.title: Hong Kong Must Have Framework to Recognize Same-Sex Unions, Court Rules
item.description: The ruling by the city’s Court of Final Appeal stops short of recognizing same-sex marriage, but some experts see the outcome as a small step forward.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Same-sex couples at an event to raise awareness of gay rights in Hong Kong in 2019, shortly after Taiwan’s government became the first in Asia to legalize same-sex marriage.

item.title: Northern Ireland Police Chief Simon Byrne Resigns Amid Mounting Scandals
item.description: A data breach and a court ruling have piled pressure on a police force that was founded on a promise to move past sectarian strife.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Liam McBurney/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Chief Constable Simon Byrne resigned from his position as head of Northern Ireland’s police force on Monday.

item.title: South Korean Teachers Rally for Protections From Harassing Parents
item.description: For months, tens of thousands of educators have protested nationwide against a rule they say keeps them from disciplining students for fear of being accused of child abuse.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: South Korean teachers at a rally in front of the National Assembly in Seoul on Monday.

item.title: North Korea Finds New Leverage in the Ukraine War
item.description: Kim Jong-un is likely to seek missile and warhead technology in an expected visit to Russia, and he is already getting a public embrace he has long sought.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: North Korea leader Kim Jong-un with Russia’s President Vladimir V. Putin in Vladivostok, Russia, in 2019. Russia has long been a crucial ally for the isolated North Korea.

item.title: Earthquake sensors are helping document Russian bombings in new detail.
item.dc:creator: James Glanz and Josh Holder

item.title: This is how military service is sold on Russian TV.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Alina Lobzina, Sarah Kerr and Natalie Reneau

item.title: Vanuatu Prime Minister Is Ousted Amid Criticism of Being Pro-West
item.description: The prime minister of Vanuatu lost his job after he was criticized for veering too close to the West. He accuses his successor of being too cozy with China.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Christopher Cottrell
item.media:description: When President Emmanuel Macron of France, center left, visited Port Vila, Vanuatu’s capital, in July, he was welcomed by Ishmael Kalsakau, then the prime minister.
